publicwhip.spmotion: *S2M-1354# Rob Gibson: Local Healthy Food for Highland Schools-That the Parliament congratulates Highland Council for its decision to source locally as much of its £2.5 million contracts for foodstuffs, including fresh fruit and vegetables, as possible, to promote food education for children and parents alike; welcomes the decision of the council's Education, Culture and Sport Committee to raise awareness among local suppliers whose successful tenders included the supply of organic fruit and vegetables; believes that the proposed pilot in Strathpeffer Primary School based on the principles of "Food for Life" is a most welcome step that sets a good example by insisting that 50% or more food is sourced locally, with ingredients to include 30% organic and 75% unprocessed foodstuffs, and praises the council's public procurement policy as part of major moves towards the aim of maximum local sourcing to provide best quality school meals that can be produced within budget constraints.

S2M-1354# Local Healthy Food for Highland Schools (lodged on 24 May 2004) Jim Mather*, Mrs Margaret Ewing*, Shiona Baird*, Richard Lochhead*, Mr Stewart Maxwell*, Fergus Ewing*, Eleanor Scott*, Mr Jamie Stone*, Frances Curran*, Mary Scanlon*

S2M-1354# Rob Gibson: Local Healthy Food for Highland Schools-That the Parliament congratulates Highland Council for its decision to source locally as much of its £2.5 million contracts for foodstuffs, including fresh fruit and vegetables, as possible, to promote food education for children and parents alike; welcomes the decision of the council's Education, Culture and Sport Committee to raise awareness among local suppliers whose successful tenders included the supply of organic fruit and vegetables; believes that the proposed pilot in Strathpeffer Primary School based on the principles of "Food for Life" is a most welcome step that sets a good example by insisting that 50% or more food is sourced locally, with ingredients to include 30% organic and 75% unprocessed foodstuffs, and praises the council's public procurement policy as part of major moves towards the aim of maximum local sourcing to provide best quality school meals that can be produced within budget constraints. *The member has provided the following Gaelic translation: Rob Gibson: Biadh Fallainn às an Sgìre airson Sgoiltean na Gàidhealtachd - Gu bheil a' Phàrlamaid a' cur meal-a-naidheachd air co-dhùnadh Comhairle na Gàidhealtachd a bhith a' faighinn an uiread sa ghabhas de bhiadh às an sgìre ionadail, a' gabhail a-steach measan agus glasraich ùra, gus foghlam bidhe a bhrosnachadh airson an dà chuid clann is pàrantan; gu bheil i a' cur meal-a-naidheachd air co-dhùnadh comataidh an Fhoghlaim, a' Chultair agus an Spòrs luchd-solair na sgìre a dhèanamh mothachail air seo, agus cuid dhiubh cheana air a bhith soirbheachail a' cur a-steach tairgsean airson mheasan agus ghlasrach organach; gu bheil i den bheachd gu bheil am pìolait a tha air a mholadh do Bhunsgoil Shrath Pheofhair, a tha stèidhichte air prionnsabalan "Biadh airson Beatha", na cheum math a tha a' nochdadh deagh eisimpleir tro a bhith a' stèidheachadh gum tig co-dhiù 50% den bhiadh às an sgìre ionadail, agus gum bi 30% den bhiadh seo organach agus gum bi 75% dheth gun ghiollachd; agus gu bheil i a' moladh poileasaidh solair na Comhairle mar phàirt de ghluasad mòr a dh' ionnsaigh a bhith a' faighinn an uiread sa ghabhas de bhiadh gu h-ionadail gus dèanamh cinnteach gum faodar biadh sgoile aig an ìre as fhèarr a dhèanamh taobh a-staigh chuingeadan buidseit.* Supported by: Patrick Harvie*, Linda Fabiani*, Chris Ballance*, Michael Matheson*, Ms Sandra White*
